title: 105_hr1807
content: Amendments to the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 include a new section that limits lifetime aggregate limits for employees. The new section in the Employee Retirement Income Security Act of 1974 sets limits on lifetime aggregate limits for group health plans and insurance coverage. The limits are $5,000,000 for the first 3 plan years and $10,000,000 for subsequent years. Small employers with fewer than 20 employees are exempt from these limits. Small employers with fewer than 20 employees are exempt from lifetime aggregate limits for group health plans and insurance coverage. Rules similar to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 apply for determining employer size. The term 'aggregate dollar lifetime limit' refers to a dollar limitation on total benefits under a group health plan or insurance coverage for an individual or coverage unit. The definition includes predecessors of an employer. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. The Act is amended to include new items after section 712, as per the Newborns' and Mothers' Health Protection Act of 1996 and the Mental Health Parity Act of 1996. The Act is amended to include a new section, "SEC. 2706. LIMITATION ON LIFETIME AGGREGATE LIMITS," which applies to plan years starting two years after the enactment date. The Act includes a new section that prohibits group health plans and health insurance issuers from imposing lifetime dollar limits below $5,000,000 for the first 3 years and $10,000,000 for subsequent years on benefits. This does not apply to group health plans for small employers with fewer than 20 employees.
